The Federal Activities Inventory Reform Act of 1998 requires executive agencies to submit annual lists of activities not inherently governmental in nature to the Office of Management and Budget by the end of the third quarter of each fiscal year. The list must include the fiscal year when the activity first appeared on the list. The Federal Activities Inventory Reform Act of 1998 mandates executive agencies to submit annual lists of non-inherently governmental activities to the Office of Management and Budget. The list includes details such as the number of employees needed for the activity and a contact person for more information. The Director of OMB reviews the agency's list and consults with the agency head before finalizing it for public availability. Upon completion of the review and consultation, the executive agency head must transmit the list to Congress and make it public. The Office of Management and Budget Director will publish a notice in the Federal Register. Any changes to the list must be promptly made available to the public. The executive agency head must review activities on a list and use a competitive process when considering contracting with a private sector source for those activities. Any changes to the list must be made public and transmitted to Congress. The executive agency head must use a competitive process to select a source for contracting with a private sector for activities on a list. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget will provide guidance for this process. Cost comparisons between private sector and in-house performance must be realistic and fair. When selecting a source for contracting with a private sector for activities, the executive agency head must ensure that all costs are considered, including quality assurance, technical monitoring, liability insurance, and overhead costs. The costs should be realistic and fair. SEC. 3. CHALLENGES TO THE LIST. An interested party can challenge the omission or inclusion of an activity on a published list. Interested party is defined as a private sector source with a direct economic interest in performing the activity. An interested party with a direct economic interest in performing the activity can challenge its omission or inclusion on a published list. This includes representatives of business associations, officers or employees of organizations within executive agencies, and heads of labor organizations. An interested party can challenge the inclusion or omission on a published list within 30 days of its public availability. Within 28 days of receiving a challenge, an official designated by the executive agency must decide and notify the party submitting the challenge. An interested party has the right to appeal an adverse decision made by an official within 10 days of receiving notification. The head of the executive agency must decide on the appeal within 10 days and provide a written notification to the party. The head of the executive agency must decide on the appeal within 10 days and transmit a written notification of the decision to the party submitting the appeal. SEC. 4. APPLICABILITY. This Act applies to executive agencies including executive departments, military departments, and independent establishments, as defined in title 5 of the United States Code. Exceptions include the General Accounting Office and Government corporations. Government corporation or Government controlled corporation, as defined in section 103 of title 5, United States Code, Nonappropriated funds instrumentality within a department or agency where all employees are referred to in section 2105(c) of title 5, United States Code, and Certain depot-level maintenance and repair of the Department of Defense as defined in section 2460 of title 10, United States Code. SEC. 5. DEFINITIONS. In this Act, "Federal Government source" refers to any organization within an executive agency using Federal Government employees for an activity. An "inherently governmental function" is a function requiring performance by Federal Government employees due to its intimate relation to the public interest. An inherently governmental function involves discretion in applying Federal Government authority and making value judgments, including interpreting and executing laws to bind the United States or determine actions. The curr_chunk describes the various ways in which the United States can protect its interests through military, diplomatic, judicial, or managerial actions, affecting private individuals and controlling government officers and property. The curr_chunk defines the term "functions" in the context of the United States, specifically related to the collection, control, or disbursement of federal funds. Excluded functions include providing advice to government officials and ministerial tasks like building security and housekeeping. The curr_chunk involves facilities operations and maintenance, warehouse operations, motor vehicle fleet management operations, or routine electrical/mechanical services. The Act will be effective on October 1, 1998.
